alert.note: Alert for Horry; Marion (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wilmington (Northeastern South Carolina and Southeastern North Carolina - Wilmington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued August 31 at 9:35PM EDT until September 05 at 1:08PM EDT by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Carolina...South Carolina... Northeast Cape Fear River Near Burgaw affecting Pender County. Lumber River 1 SE Nichols affecting Horry, Dillon and Marion Counties. Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and Marion Counties. Black Creek At Quinby affecting Florence and Darlington Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...North Carolina... Black River At Kingstree affecting Williamsburg County. Lumber River Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in South Carolina... Great Pee Dee River At Pee Dee affecting Florence and Marion Counties. For the Northeast Cape Fear River...including Burgaw...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Lumber River...including Nichols, Pembroke, Lumberton Usgs Gage, Maxton, Lumberton, Boardman...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Little Pee Dee River...including Galivants Ferry...Major flooding is forecast. For the Black Creek...including Black Creek Nr Hartsville, Quinby... Minor flooding is forecast. For the Black River...including Kingstree...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Black Creek at Quinby. * WHEN...Until early Tuesday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 13.5 feet, Floodwaters begin to affect one mobile home on Creekside Drive and continue to rise in yards. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 10.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 13.6 feet early Sunday morning. It will then fall below flood stage early Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=ilm . The next statement will be issued by this evening.
